'''''Amanita brunnescens''''', also known as the '''brown American star-footed Amanita'''<ref name="A. brunnescens@Amanita Studies">{{cite web |last=Tulloss|first=R.|url=http://www.amanitaceae.org/?Amanita+brunnescens|title=''Amanita brunnescens'' G. F. Atk. |work=Amanitaceae.org  |accessdate=2012-12-27}}</ref> or '''cleft-footed amanita''' is a native North American [[mushroom]] of the large genus ''[[Amanita]]''. Originally presumed to be ''[[Amanita phalloides]]'' by renowned American mycologist [[Charles Horton Peck]], it was described and named by [[George F. Atkinson]] of [[Cornell University]]. He named it after the fact that it bruised brown.<ref name = "Litten75">{{cite journal |author=Litten W. |year=1975 |title=The most poisonous mushrooms |journal=[[Scientific American]] |volume=232 |issue=3 |pages=90–101 |doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0375-90 |pmid=1114308}}</ref>

It differs from the death cap by its fragile [[Volva (mycology)|volva]] and tendency to bruise brown.
